chunk_text: Mediterranean diet is the golden standard for healthy nutrition and is associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular events.1 Traditionally, Mediterranean diet is characterized by high intake of fruits, vegetables, cereals, fish and moderate wine consumption, with scarce intake of dairy products and red meat. Most important, the health benefits of Mediterranean diet have been attributed to the high intake of monounsaturated fat, mostly represented by extra virgin olive oil (Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO)). Thus, recent results from the PREDIMED study showed that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) added to the Mediterranean diet reduces the risk of cardiovascular events compared with controls.1 Among the mechanism(s) potentially attributable to the antiatherosclerotic effect, the prevention of new-onset diabetes might have a role, but the biologic plausibility of such positive association is still unclear.

Prevention of diabetes might be attributable to the antioxidant property of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO);2 thus, oxidative stress seems to be implicated in β-cells dysfunction and eventually diabetes.3 Furthermore, oxidative stress is responsible for activation of dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4),4 which cleaves incretins downregulating insulin secretion.5 We have recently demonstrated that a Mediterranean-type meal supplemented with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) is associated with reduced post-prandial oxidative stress generated by NOX2, the catalytic subunit of NADPH oxidase.6 On the basis of this finding, we speculated that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO), added to Mediterranean-type meal, could improve post-prandial glycaemic control via an oxidative stress-mediated mechanism.

In addition, we investigated if Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) had any effect on lipid profile including analysis of low-density lipoprotein (low density lipoprotein (LDL))-cholesterol (low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C), triglycerides and high-density lipoprotein (high density lipoprotein (HDL))-cholesterol (high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C).

Twenty-five healthy subjects (HS; 12 males and 13 females) gave informed consent to participate in the interventional study, which was performed between January 2013 and March 2013. Study methodology, clinical and demographics characteristics of HS and Mediterranean-type lunch have been previously reported.6 Briefly, a first study consisted in randomizing 25 HS were to receive a typical Mediterranean lunch including or not 10 g of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) (Lago dei Papi, Viterbo, Italy; see Table 1, Supplementary Data) in a cross-over design; there was an interval of 30 days between the two phases of the study. Mediterranean-type lunch consisted of pasta (100 g), chicken breast (150 g), salad (80 g), bread (80 g), apple (200 g) for a total of 894 calories.

After 1 month from the end of the first study the same subjects (n=25) participated to a second study in which they were randomly allocated to receive a lunch with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) (10 g) or corn oil (10 g) in a cross-over design. There was an interval of 30 days between the two phases of the study. For each phase of the study, a blood sample was taken before (at 1300 hours) and 2 h after the lunch. Every blood determination was performed blind. None of the participants were receiving antioxidants supplements or statin. The study was conformed to the ethical guidelines of the 1975 Declaration of Helsinki and was approved by the Ethical Committee of Sapienza University.

Laboratory analysis Blood concentration of glucose, insulin, total GLP1 (7–36 and 9–36 peptides), total glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), DPP-4 protein and activity, ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL), low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C, triglycerides and high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C were measured by ELISA Kit (Sigma Aldrich, DRG International, Cusabio, Boster). Oil analysis were described in Supplementary Data.  Sample size As regards the interventional cross-over study, we computed the minimum sample size with respect to a two-tailed one-sample Student's t-test, considering as (i) glucose variation to be detected between extra virgin oil and corn oil treatment |δ|≥15 mg dl−1, (ii) s.d. of the paired differences s.d.=15 mg dl−1, (iii) type I error probability α=0.05 and power 1−β=0.90. This resulted in a minimum sample size of 10 per group.

Categorical variables are reported as counts (percentage) and continuous variables as means±s.d. unless otherwise indicated. Independence of categorical variables was tested by χ2-test. Comparisons between groups were carried out by Student's t-test and were replicated as appropriate with nonparametric tests (Kolmogorov–Smirnov (z) test in case of nonhomogeneous variances as verified by Levene's test).  The cross-over study data were analyzed for the assessment of treatment and period effects, by performing a split-plot ANOVA with one between-subject factor (treatment sequence) and two within-subject factors (period 1 vs 2; pre- vs post-treatment). The analysis was performed separately to compare a meal with and without Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) and a meal with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) vs corn oil. The full model was considered, allowing for the assessment of all main effects and interactions.

Pairwise comparisons were corrected by the Bonferroni test; results were expressed as means±s.e. Bivariate analysis was performed by Spearman rank correlation test. A value of P<0.05 was considered statistically significant. All analyses were carried out with SPSS V.18.0 (SPSS Statistics v. 18.0, SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

In the first study, 2 h after meal, subjects who assumed a meal with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) had significantly lower blood glucose (P<0.001), DPP-4 protein (P<0.001) and activity (P<0.001), low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C (P<0.001) and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) (P<0.001) and higher insulin (P<0.05), GLP-1 (P<0.001) and glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) (P<0.05) compared with those without Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO). The second study showed that compared with corn oil, Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) improved both glycemic and lipid profile. Thus, a significantly smaller increase of glucose (P<0.05), DPP4 protein (P<0.001) and activity (P<0.05) and higher increase of insulin (P<0.001) and GLP-1 (P<0.001) were observed. Furthermore, compared with corn oil, Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) showed a significantly less increase of low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C (P<0.05) and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) (P<0.001).

Conclusions: We report for the first time that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) improves post-prandial glucose and low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C, an effect that may account for the antiatherosclerotic effect of the Mediterranean diet. ==== Body Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) vs non-Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) effect on post-prandial glycaemic control In the first study, we compared the effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) added or not to a Mediterranean-type lunch. At baseline, no differences in blood variables were detected (Figure 1). Two hours after a Mediterranean-type lunch, a significant difference for treatments (meal with vs without Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO)) was found with respect to glucose (F=27.8, P<0.001; Figure 1a), insulin (F=38.3, P<0.001; Figure 1b), GLP1 (F=31.0, P<0.001; Figure 1c), glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) (F=5.3, P=0.025; Figure 1d), DPP-4 concentration (F=62.9, P<0.001; Figure 1e) and DPP-4 activity (F=16.0, P<0.001; Figure 1f).

In particular, compared with baseline, when a meal not containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) was given, glucose concentration and insulin increased significantly (Figures 1a and b; Table 1). Conversely, compared with baseline, in subjects given a meal containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO), a less increase of blood glucose and a more marked increase of blood insulin were detected (Figures 1a and b; Table 1).  Analysis of incretins' secretion showed significant differences between the meal with and without Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO). Thus, incretins increased more significantly in subjects supplemented with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) compared with those who did not receive it (Figures 1c and d; Table 1); furthermore, DPP-4 protein and activity showed a lower increase after meal with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) (Figures 1e and f; Table 1).

Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) vs non-Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) effect on post-prandial lipid profile At baseline, no differences of blood variables were detected (Figure 2). Two hours after a Mediterranean-type lunch, a significant difference for treatments (meal with vs without Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO)) was found with respect to low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C (F=6.4, P=0.014; Figure 2a) and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) (F=144.0, P<0.001; Figure 2b). No significant difference was found with respect to triglycerides and high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C (Figures 2c and d). In particular, compared with baseline, when a meal not containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) was given, low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C, ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) and triglycerides increased significantly, whereas high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C did not change (Figures 2a–d; Table 1).

Conversely, compared with baseline, in subjects given a meal containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO), a significantly less increase of low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) was detected, whereas triglycerides and high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C did not change (Figures 2a–d; Table 1). Δ of ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) correlated with Δ of glycaemia (RS: 0.501; P<0.001), Δ of insulin (RS:-0.492; P<0.001), Δ of DPP-4 activity (RS: 0.467; P=0.001), Δ of DPP-4 concentration (RS=0.508; P<0.001) and Δ of GLP1 (RS: −0.353; P=0.012). Δ of DPP-4 activity correlated with serum glucose (RS: 0.503; P=0.001).  Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) and corn oil effect on post-prandial glycaemic and lipid profile When we compared the effect of a meal containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) or corn oil, a significant difference for treatments with respect to glucose (F=13.9, P=0.01; Figure 3a), insulin (F=14.4, P<0.001; Figure 3b), GLP1 (F=55.6, P<0.

001; Figure 3c), DPP-4 concentration (F=23.0, P<0.001; Figure 3e), DPP-4 activity (F=12.5, P=0.001; Figure 3f), low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C (F=4.1, P<0.05; Figure 4a) and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) (F=67.5, P<0.001; Figure 4b) was detected. No significant difference for treatments was found with respect to glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), triglycerides and high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C (Figures 3d and 4c and d).  In particular, after 2 h from lunch, in subjects given a meal containing corn oil, glucose concentration, insulin, GLP1, glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), DPP-4 concentration and DPP-4 activity increased significantly (Figure 3a–f; Table 2). These changes were associated with a significant increase of low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C, ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) and triglycerides, whereas high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C did not significantly change (Figure 4a–d; Table 2).

Compared with corn oil, subjects given a meal containing Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) showed a significantly less increase of blood glucose, DPP-4 concentration and activity and a more marked increase of blood insulin, GLP1, glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) (Figure 3a–f; Table 2). Concerning lipid profile, subjects given Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) showed a significantly smaller increase of low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL), whereas triglycerides showed a non-significant trend toward reduction (Figures 4a–d; Table 2).

This is the first study demonstrating that a Mediterranean-type meal supplemented with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) has a beneficial effect on post-prandial glycemic and lipid profile by decreasing blood glucose, low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C and ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL).  There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that post-prandial changes of glycemic and lipid profile might have deleterious effect on vascular disease by promoting and/or aggravating the atherosclerotic process.7, 8 Moreover, post-prandial glucose has been associated with an higher incidence of cardiovascular events in patients with9 and without diabetes.10 Thus, blunting or minimizing post-prandial glycemic and lipid profile could have a positive impact in the progression of atherosclerosis.

11 Observational and interventional studies consistently demonstrated a potentially beneficial effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on the atherosclerotic process,1, 12, 13 but the underlying mechanism is still undefined. Data regarding the impact of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on post-prandial glycemic and lipid profile are still lacking. The novelty of the present study is in the demonstration that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) improves the post-prandial glycemic control by lowering and increasing blood glucose and insulin, respectively. Post-prandial glycemic control is regulated by incretins, which upregulate insulin secretion and in turn lowers blood glucose. Incretins such as GLP1 and glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) are secreted by distal small intestine in response to its stimulation, bind receptors in the endocrine pancreas so eliciting insulin secretion and lowering post-prandial blood glucose and are rapidly inactivated by DPP-4.

14, 15 Our approach was to evaluate whether Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) may stimulate intestinal cells and trigger endogenous incretin release. Analysis of GLP-1 and glucose dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) after Mediterranean-type lunch demonstrated that supplementation with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) was associated with an increase of both incretins coincidentally with a decrease of DPP-4 activity suggesting that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) behaves as a DPP-4 inhibitor. The antioxidant effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO)6 may account for the improved post-prandial glycaemia as oxidative stress is implicated in incretin secretion and metabolism. Oxidative stress affects, in fact, insulin signaling cascade, leading to insulin resistance3 and cumulative hyperglycemia and resultant AGE-induced ROS generation16 might impair the incretins' effects via elevation of circulating DPP-4 concentration.

4 Of note, we found that, compared with control, post-prandial ox-low density lipoprotein (LDL) increase was almost blunted by Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) and paralleled DPP-4 activity changes with a direct correlation between these two variables, reinforcing the concept that oxidative stress upregulates DPP-4 activity4 and eventually inhibits insulin secretion. Among the Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) components, oleuropein would be likely to downregulate NOX-2-derived oxidative stress,6 but further study is necessary to investigate if the polyphenol component of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) also have a role.  An unexpected finding of the study was the improvement of lipid profile observed after Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) administration. Thus, post-prandial serum low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C was significantly reduced compared with control suggesting a lipid-lowering effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO).

This effect seems to be specific for low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C, as neither triglycerides nor high density lipoprotein (HDL)-C were modified compared with control. The positive impact of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on post-prandial low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C is more difficult to interpret. We have not data that may help to explain if such beneficial effect depends on a specific Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) interference with cholesterol absorption in the gastrointestinal tract or on a direct activity of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on cholesterol biosynthesis. This issue deserves further investigation.  To investigate if these changes on serum glucose and low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C were peculiar for Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO), we compared Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) versus corn oil with regard to the changes of post-prandial glycemic and lipid profile.

Also this experiment confirmed the beneficial effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) as it significantly improved both glycemic and lipid profile compared with corn oil so suggesting that its components may favorably influence glucose and cholesterol metabolism.  The study has limitation and implication. We have not data specifically addressing insulin secretion because early serum glucose and insulin increment after lunch are not available.17 The exact mechanism through which Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) downregulates DPP-4 has not been addressed in the present study and should be investigated. It is possible that Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) downregulates NOX2-derived oxidative stress,6 but it cannot be excluded that post-prandial low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C lowering may also have a role.18 We cannot exclude that corn oil may have positive effect when compared with control as this issue was not investigated in the present study.

The study has been performed in healthy subjects and, therefore, further study is necessary to see whether Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) has such beneficial effect in patients with diabetes or dyslipidemia. Finally it remains to establish whether the changes observed with Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) persist chronically.  While our findings provide a potential explanation for the inverse association between Mediterranean diet and diabetes risk, as GLP-1 may reduce cellular apoptosis in the pancreatic β-cells and promote β-cell proliferation,15 the positive effect of Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on insulin and low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C opens new avenues to counteract the potentially deleterious effects on vascular function related to post-prandial spikes in glucose and lipid.

19  In conclusion, Extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) has beneficial effect on post-prandial glycemic and low density lipoprotein (LDL)-C profile so providing a novel insight into the mechanism potentially accounting for the antiatherosclerotic effect of the Mediterranean diet.  Violi designed research, wrote paper, had primary responsibility for final content; Carnevale designed research, wrote paper; Bartimoccia and Nocella conducted research; Loffredo, Cangemi, and Pastori analyzed data and performed statistical analysis; Angelico and Pignatelli recruited participants for the study.
